subject: Criminal
title: People vs. Genosa (G.R. No. 135981)
ratio: Recognized Battered Woman Syndrome (BWS). A woman who has suffered at least three cycles of violence may validly claim self-defense even if the aggression was not 'imminent' in the traditional sense.

subject: Criminal
title: People vs. Oanis (74 Phil. 257)
ratio: Mistake of Fact is a defense only if the act would have been lawful had the facts been as the accused believed them to be. Police killing a sleeping man they thought was a fugitive is Murder, not mistake of fact.

subject: Criminal
title: Pro Reo Doctrine
ratio: When a law or fact is susceptible to two interpretations—one lenient to the accused and one strict—the interpretation favorable to the accused must be adopted.
mnemonic: Pro Reo: Doubt goes to Accused

subject: Criminal
title: People vs. Guillen (85 Phil. 307)
ratio: Error in personae (mistake in identity) or Aberratio Ictus (mistake in blow) does not exempt the accused from criminal liability but may result in a complex crime under Article 48.

subject: Criminal
title: Praeter Intentionem
ratio: A mitigating circumstance where the injurious result is greater than that intended. Requires a notable disparity between the means employed and the resulting felony.

subject: Criminal
title: Complex Crime (Art. 48)
ratio: Occurs when a single act constitutes two or more grave or less grave felonies, or when an offense is a necessary means for committing the other. Penalty for the most serious crime is imposed in its maximum period.
